timeline.title: LaLiga and Internet Blocking in Spain
timeline.subtitle: A timeline of events and their impact on digital infrastructure
timeline.warning: This is a documented case study. Legal precedents established may influence future digital policy decisions in the EU.

2024-12-18.title: LaLiga Gets Legal Approval to Block Websites
2024-12-18.description: LaLiga received permission from a Barcelona court to ask internet providers (like Movistar, Vodafone, and Orange) to block websites streaming football matches illegally.
2024-12-18.impact: This set the stage for blocking internet addresses (IPs) used by services hosting pirated content.

2025-02-09.title: LaLiga Begins Blocking Cloudflare IPs
2025-02-09.description: LaLiga began blocking internet addresses tied to Cloudflare, a major infrastructure service that provides CDN and security services to websites.
2025-02-09.impact: The blocks resulted in disruption of thousands of legitimate websites in Spain, including small businesses and government sites.
2025-02-09.why: Cloudflare provides services to more than 240 million websites globally, representing approximately 20% of the world's web infrastructure.

2025-02-19.title: Cloudflare Files Legal Challenge
2025-02-19.description: Cloudflare and RootedCON filed a legal challenge against LaLiga, questioning the proportionality of IP blocks that affected legitimate users and businesses.
2025-02-19.impact: They argued the blocks were overly broad, affecting critical infrastructure beyond the specific target.

2025-03-26.title: Cloudflare Loses Appeal
2025-03-26.description: A court (the same that approved the initial order in December 2024) rejected Cloudflare's appeal, allowing LaLiga to keep blocking IPs.
2025-03-26.impact: This meant disruptions would continue, especially during football match weekends.

2025-04-12.title: Vercel Receives Block Notifications
2025-04-12.description: LaLiga sent notifications to Vercel, a hosting and deployment platform, claiming it was hosting content that infringed copyright.
2025-04-12.impact: Blocks targeting Vercel's IPs disrupted websites used by developers and businesses utilizing the platform.
2025-04-12.why: Vercel is a deployment platform used by more than 9 million websites, particularly popular among developers and development teams.

2025-04-15.title: Vercel Speaks Out
2025-04-15.description: Vercel's CEO, Guillermo Rauch, publicly criticized the blocks, explaining that they harmed legitimate websites and developers.
2025-04-15.impact: Vercel reported working with LaLiga to resolve the issue but noted the blocks were overly aggressive.

2025-05-04.title: Twitch and Others Affected
2025-05-04.description: LaLiga's blocks hit more platforms, including Twitch, a popular streaming service.
2025-05-04.impact: IPs for Twitch and other services like Netlify were blocked, causing outages for gamers, developers, and businesses.

2025-05-20.title: Cloudflare's CEO Warns of Dangers
2025-05-20.description: Cloudflare's CEO, Matthew Prince, spoke out on X, calling LaLiga's strategy 'bonkers' and warning that blocking critical IPs could harm emergency services and even cost lives.
2025-05-20.impact: He said Cloudflare is willing to help but wants targeted solutions.

2025-07-06.title: Blocks Continue, No Major Resolution
2025-07-06.description: As of today, blocks continue without significant resolution.
2025-07-06.impact: Spain's internet continues to be regularly disrupted, affecting millions of legitimate users.

otherPractices.title: A History of Controversy
otherPractices.subtitle: This isn't the first time LaLiga's actions have been questioned. Below are summaries of other notable cases.

cases.title: The Spy App
cases.abstract: In 2018, LaLiga's mobile app was found to be using users' microphones and GPS to spy on bars illegally streaming games. This led to a €250,000 GDPR fine, which was later overturned, but the practice was widely condemned as a breach of privacy.

cases.title: Biometric Surveillance
cases.abstract: In 2023, LaLiga faced a €1 million fine for implementing facial recognition in stadiums without a proper data protection impact assessment, raising concerns over mass surveillance of fans.

cases.title: Surveillance through the LaLiga App (2018-2019)
cases.content:
In 2018, LaLiga updated its mobile application, used by millions of users, to include a feature that activated the phone's microphone to detect the unauthorized broadcasting of football matches in public venues like bars and restaurants. This functionality used audio fingerprinting technology to identify match broadcasts and combined it with location data to flag unlicensed venues. In June 2019, the Spanish Agency for Data Protection (AEPD) fined LaLiga €250,000 for infringing the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

The AEPD determined that LaLiga failed to clearly inform users about the use of their microphones and location data, thereby breaching transparency rules (Article 5.1, GDPR) and the right to withdraw consent (Article 7.3, GDPR). The agency required LaLiga to display a notification, such as an icon, each time the microphone was activated. LaLiga argued that the app only captured a small part of the audio (0.75%) as a digital fingerprint, not conversations, and that users gave their consent during installation. They appealed the fine and deactivated the function on June 30, 2019.

cases.title: Biometric Surveillance in Stadiums (2021-Ongoing)
cases.content:
Since 2021, LaLiga has been implementing a biometric access system in football stadiums, which uses facial recognition to verify fans' identities. The system, developed with a technology partner, aims to improve security and streamline entry into venues. Fans who opt-in have their facial data scanned and linked to their ticket information, allowing them to enter the stadium without presenting a physical ticket or ID.

However, this initiative has raised significant privacy concerns. Critics argue that the collection and storage of sensitive biometric data create a high-risk database that could be vulnerable to breaches. There are also concerns about function creep—the possibility of this data being used for purposes beyond ticketing, such as surveillance or commercial profiling, without explicit user consent. Data protection authorities and digital rights groups have called for greater transparency on how the data is stored, secured, and for how long it is retained, emphasizing the need to comply with the stringent requirements of GDPR for processing special category data like biometrics.
